text:
Graham Hovey — Letter from Italy Ho. 8
, Recorded in Rome, December 22, 1953
Tape runs 13 minutes
This is Graham Hovey, reporting from Rome with another radio
Letter from Italy, produced for the Rational Association of Educational
Broadcasters with the cooperation of Radio Italians*
In previous Letters X have taken a look at the two extremes in
Italian politics. I have examined the possibility that Italy might be
drifting back to Fascism. And I have examined some factors in the growing
strength of the Italian Communists.
Italy cannot go Fascist and Communist at the same time, of course.
But the simultaneous drift toward the two extremes and away from the demo¬
cratic middle 1s a familiar phenomenon in politics. The national elections
of last June 7 demonstrated that his trend is continuing in Italy.
On the far right, the neo-Fascist Italian Social Movement polled
a million and a half votes and increased its representation in the Chamber
of Deputies from six to 29 seats. The Monarchist party polled a million
800 thousand votes and boosted its Chamber delegation from 14 to 40.
On the far left, the Communists and left Socialists together
gained a million and a half votes over their eight million figure of 1948
and increased their overall representation in the Chamber from 183 to 218.
The Fascists and Monarchists have gained by exploiting a variety
of Italian frustrations and discontents. The Communists and left Socialists
have done this too, but they also have worked unceasingly at the onerous
Job of party organisation and the task of identifying themselves unmistakably
with the interests of workers and peasants.
One can say all this without entirely explaining away that drift
away from the democratic middle. What I am saying is that the parties be¬
longing to that democratic middle road must shoulder some of the responsibi¬
lity. It has been their weaknesses, as well as the other factors I have
listed, that account for the growing strength of the far left and the louder
noises emanating from the far right.
It follows that these democratic parties must correct their weak¬
nesses; must do a more adequate Job, if the delicate Italian democracy is to
survive and grow stronger. Well, then, what are the prospects?
At the moment, the strongest of these parties; the strongest party
in Italy, has the responsiblity of governing the country. I refer, of course,
to the Christian Democratic party. Last June, the Christian Democrats
polled nearly 11 million votes and won 262 Chamber seats. That represented
a loss of two million votes and 43 seats over the party's 1948 showing.
Partly as the result of those losses, the Christian Democracy is
obviously in a period of transition at the moment. Premier Giuseppe Pella
must depend on Monarchist support for his parliamentary majority, but no
one knows how long that will be forthcoming and at what price. The party
has shown some signs of disintegration.
